history.content:
Hi there,

I hope someone else gets back to you as well, but we're definitely aware of the problem and have been working hard for years to try to address it. Unfortunately, funding and the building or new classrooms has not kept up with the increase in student interested in EECS. Staff and Faculty do a lot to try to accommodate as many students as possible, including writing grant proposals to industry partners to acquire more TA funding. We know it's frustrating. 

Unfortunately, it looks like you prioritized three non-EECS courses for your phase 1, and the course you tried in phase 2 is already at 70% capacity. If students drop, you will receive priority over non-majors, until everyone has has their phase 2 appointment.

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy

CS C100 is a CS upper-div and it has seats available and it has seats available that are reserved for juniors and seniors.

---------------------------------

CS186 is currently open as well, with seats reserved for CS majors.

Also, just a tip: its wise to Phase I the classes you absolutely need to take (especially if you're already a declared CS major). Even if you can't enroll, make sure to waitlist because that greatly increases your chances of getting into the class (from my experience, you almost always get in if you persist).

I feel that if this tip is followed, you can eventually get into any class regardless of your year/appointment time (except for a few very high demand classes like EECS127, CS188, CS168, etc.).

children.subject: CS 170 & CS 186 are not yet at 70% mark

history.content:
It seems like every CS Upper Div course is full with an enormous waitlist. As a graduating junior, I need to take at least two more CS UDs and it would be ridiculous if I could not get into any because they are all filled up.

It is not even a matter of not getting into a course that interests me, which I cannot. But, more over an issue of not being able to get into a course within my department.

Is the department aware of this or even doing anything to address this? Because this severely affects the quality of our education. If the major enrollment is increasing, shouldn't the department increase the number of course offerings or the size of the courses? I apologize if I am wrong in my assumptions, but from the student's perspective, many of us have been unable to get into any CS courses.
history.subject: Are there any non-full UD CS classes?
